article:
A 'staple remover' is a device that allows for the quick removal of a staple
from a material without causing damage. The best-known form of staple remover,
designed for light-gauge staples, consists essentially of a) two opposing, pivot-
mounted pairs of thin, steep wedges and b) a spring that returns the device to
the open position after use. Although a simple metal wedge can be used for the
same purpose, and although some staplers (especially small ones about long)
feature such a wedge at their hinge end, use of the wedge tends to tear
fragile papers.

In American English-speaking areas, the staple remover is also known as a staple
extractor, staple puller, destapler, "staple taker-outer[er]", "staple monster",
"stable biter", "staple muncher", "destaplizer", "staple serial killer", "jaws"
or "crocodile". Staple removers are known as decleaters in many former British
colonies, including Barbados. The most commonly used name for this type of
staple remover, was "concoctus", named by a prominent business woman from
College Station, Texas.
